The numerator of the inversion asymmetry parameter $\mathcal{A}$ is the expectation value of an inversion-odd operator $M$ that is diagonal in the basis of reciprocal lattice momenta, with matrix element $\pm 1$ for the wavevectors $\pm \mathbf{G}_i$.  $\langle M \rangle$ is only nonzero for states with opposite inversion symmetry.


 Using the first-order expression above for $|\psi(t)\rangle$, we obtain $\langle M \rangle = M_1(t) + M_2(t)$ with
\begin{eqnarray}
M_1(t) & = & \sum_{i,j,k} \left( c^*_i c_k e^{-i (\omega_k - \omega_i)t} \alpha^*_{j,i} M_{j,k} + c.c \right) \\
M_2(t) & = & \sum_{i,j,k} \left( c^*_i c_k e^{-i (\omega_j - \omega_i)t} \left(-\alpha_{j,k}\right) M^*_{j,i} + c.c. \right)
\end{eqnarray}
and $M_{j,i} = \langle \psi_{j,-}^{(0)} | M | \psi_{i,+}^{(0)}\rangle$.

These equations show two generic scenarios that lead to a large momentum-space asymmetry.   $M_1(t)$ describes the beating between the first two terms of equation \ref{eq:TimeEv}, which represent the incorporation of inversion antisymmetry into an even eigenstate $\ket{\psi_{i,+}^{(0)}}$ of $\mathcal{H}_0$. In order for this to have a large effect, an inversion-antisymmetric state $\ket{\psi_{j,-}^{(0)}}$ must be close in energy to $\ket{\psi_{i,+}^{(0)}}$ so as to be strongly mixed by the perturbation $\mathcal{H}_a$ (giving large $\alpha_{j,i}$).  There must also be a third inversion symmetric state, $|\psi_{k,+}^{(0)}\rangle$), with which the perturbed state can interfere.  In this case, we expect also a modulation in $\mathcal{A}$ at the frequency $\omega_i - \omega_k$.  This scenario is illustrated in Fig.\ \ref{fig:ExpFig}, where we identify $\ket{\psi_{i,+}^{(0)}}$ as the ground state and $\ket{\psi_{j,-}^{(0)}}$ as the first excited state.

The second scenario, described by $M_2(t)$, involves antisymmetric unperturbed states $\ket{\psi_{j,-}^{(0)}}$, like the excited state shown in Fig.\ \ref{fig:ExpFig}.  When there is a nearby even state $|\psi_{i,+}^{(0)}\rangle$, the perturbation $\mathcal{H}_a$ introduces population at zero-momentum so that $c_j$ is nonzero.  The state $\ket{\psi_{j,-}^{(0)}}$ remains mostly antisymmetric and will interfere with all inversion even states $|\psi_{k,+}^{(0)}$ that have large population in the first-order diffraction momenta (giving large $M_{j,k}$).  In this case, we expect modulation in $\mathcal{A}$ at frequencies $\omega_j - \omega_k$.

In our experiment the lowest two energy eigenstates are only partially hybridized because $2 |V_a/V_s|$ is small compared to the energy splitting between the ground and first excited states of $\mathcal{H}_0$.  As a result, the evolution of $\mathcal{A}$ in Fig.\ \ref{fig:TimeDep} is dominated by  $M_2(t)$.  The three states that maximally contribute to $\mathcal{A}$ are illustrated in Fig.\ \ref{fig:ExpFig}, their frequency differences of 2.3 kHz and 63 kHz can be seen in the signal of $\mathcal{A}$.   

Our observations, along with the theoretical descriptions offered in this work, illustrate how matter-wave diffraction can be made highly sensitive to, and strongly manipulated by, fine features of an optical lattice.  Our work also suggests an explanation for the momentum-space asymmetry observed in time of flight diffraction of a transversely polarized rubidium condensate reported in Ref.\ \cite{solt12twisted} (see also Ref.\ \cite{jurg15twisted}).  In that experiment, the condensate was loaded into a spin-dependent optical lattice and after time of flight the spin states were separated by Stern-Gerlach, revealing an equal and opposite momentum-space asymmetry for the two spin states.  The asymmetry was interpreted as evidence of a ground-state superfluid that forms with a spatially dependent phase in the superfluid order parameter.  A later theoretical study \cite{chou13twisted} found no evidence for such a ``twisted superfluid'' state, as would be naively expected given that the optical lattice and mean-field interaction potentials are both real valued.  

We suggest that the inversion-asymmetric diffraction patterns observed in the experiment \cite{solt12twisted} may have resulted from matter-wave diffraction from the inversion-asymmetric transient honeycomb lattice that repulsion from one atomic spin state creates for the second spin state in early time of flight.  Such diffraction of one matter wave off another can be described equivalently as nonlinear coherent wave mixing induced by interatomic interactions \cite{pert10mixing}.  The observation in Ref.\ \cite{solt12twisted} that the sign of the asymmetry parameter $\mathcal{A}$  was consistent between experimental repetitions supports our view that the asymmetry resulted from deterministic matter-wave dynamics rather than by the spontaneous symmetry breaking that might have been expected for a quantum phase transition of the sort claimed in that work.  Moreover, in a recent experiment with the same system as in Ref.\ \cite{solt12twisted}, the diffraction was modified by eliminating one spin population from the lattice just before the atoms were released \cite{sengtwisted}.  The consequent elimination of the asymmetry signal is consistent with our suggested explanation.
